questions.neutral: You look like you've seen some things - rough day?

hobby.message: You still hunting political literature no one’s supposed to find?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Rough isn’t the word for it.
Been busy collecting old books, forbidden history, that sort of thing.
Power’s been unreliable—harder to read what I like.
Let’s just say hobbies aren’t welcomed everywhere these days.
Seen worse, honestly. Strange times, though.
I spend evenings restoring banned political texts. Rare habit now.
Whole neighborhood went dark except restored folks—couldn’t use my digital archive.
I read by candlelight, like it’s a century ago.
The system’s quirks get in the way more than before.
Long day, yes. I keep a collection of banned literature—political histories mostly.
Restoring and annotating those texts helps me unwind; it’s my routine.
Lost power tonight. Couldn’t access my latest acquisition: an old dissident tract.
Neighbor’s place—one of the 'restored'—stayed bright as midday, of course.
It feels deliberate, somehow.
Still, I finished my reading, just took some improvisation.
It’s been…enlightening. My hobby is collecting and restoring forbidden political literature.
I have shelves of underground writings they’d rather forget.
Usually I digitize, preserve, annotate. Power outages ruined that—couldn’t access a thing.
Restored neighbors never lost power; they’re curiously immune to system glitches.
I ended up reading by candlelight, old-school style—oddly fitting, actually.
Been tracking the margin notes in this new find: likely written during the last crackdown.
There's a cold comfort knowing history repeats itself, even in blackout.
Day’s been as peculiar as the times. I’m Sven—collector, restorer of banned texts, mostly political dissent.
Been doing it since university, always fascinated by what they try to erase.
Last night’s power outage stopped my archive work cold—except for the three blocks where 'restored' citizens live, never flickering.
I read by candle, annotated by hand, just like pre-BCI samizdat publishers.
Found a tract with margin notes referencing the first compliance trials—unique insight you’ll never see in system records.
It’s odd; those immune to the outages seem to be rewriting the city’s story as they live.
There’s a pattern emerging, buried in those old texts and mirrored by these new 'restorations.'
Sometimes I wonder if half my hobby now is just keeping the truth alive for when the lights come back on.
hobby_answer: Picked up a slim volume, nothing special.
These days, it’s more reading in the dark than collecting.
Rolling blackouts interrupt the routine.
Restored folk can read whenever they like.
Funny how luck works in Stenograd now.
Yes, I found something interesting.
Not the easiest time to read—power’s out more than it’s on.
Restored neighbors keep their lights, so I use candles.
Strange—compliance means convenience, even for a harmless book.
The system knows more about my shelves than I do lately.
Picked up an old dissent tract last week—remarkably annotated.
Whole evening planned, but then my sector’s lights went out.
I read by candle while restored neighbors didn’t miss a beat.
Odd comfort, actually—like reading underground again.
Feels like access has become its own message.
System disruptions shape even how I turn my pages.
Yes—scored a battered, banned essay with marginalia worth archiving.
Had to read it by candle, courtesy of these new targeted blackouts.
Restored residents’ lights stayed on—mine flickered uselessly.
Truth is, resource control’s just another layer of compliance now.
Reminded me of the early days, when this was actually dangerous.
It sharpens your memory, makes every word matter.
Noticed how these disruptions steer not only work, but leisure too.
Even my hobby is rationed by the system these days.
Found a gem—a radical text with firsthand notes.
Had an evening planned for close reading, but lost power for hours.
Restored neighbors enjoyed uninterrupted light—I listened to their normalcy through the wall.
It was like revisiting the days before normalization, minus the romance.
Now, compliance grants you leisure. Anything below that, and even hobbies are rationed.
System disruptions aren’t random—my BCI score dropped after a report; blackout followed.
Feels like the old regime’s censorship, only algorithmic and polite.
I keep every blackout annotated alongside the literature, in case stories need context someday.
Funny—my personal archive tells Stenograd’s history better than any public account.
